<#
.SYNOPSIS
    Replaces all occurrences of 'hello' with 'world' in a given string.
.DESCRIPTION
    This function takes a string as input and returns a new string where every instance
    of the substring 'hello' is replaced with 'world'. The replacement is case-sensitive.
.PARAMETER s
    The input string to be processed.
.EXAMPLE
    Replace-HelloWithWorld -s "hello there, hello world"
    Returns: "world there, world world"
#>
function Replace-HelloWithWorld {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [string]$s
    )

    return $s.Replace('hello', 'world')
}

<#
.SYNOPSIS
    Replaces all occurrences of 'hello' with 'world' in a given string.
.DESCRIPTION
    This function takes a string as input and returns a new string where every instance
    of the substring 'hello' is replaced with 'world'. The replacement is case-sensitive.
.PARAMETER s
    The input string to be processed.
.EXAMPLE
    Replace-HelloWithWorld -s "hello there, hello world"
    Returns: "world there, world world"
#>
function Replace-HelloWithWorld {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [string]$s
    )

    return $s.Replace('hello', 'world')
}
function Test-ReplaceHelloWithWorld {
    # Test case 1: Multiple occurrences
    $result1 = Replace-HelloWithWorld -s "hello there, hello world"
    $expected1 = "world there, world world"
    if ($result1 -ne $expected1) {
        throw "Test 1 failed. Expected: '$expected1', Actual: '$result1'"
    }

    # Test case 2: Case-sensitive (should not replace)
    $result2 = Replace-HelloWithWorld -s "Hello there"
    $expected2 = "Hello there"
    if ($result2 -ne $expected2) {
        throw "Test 2 failed. Expected: '$expected2', Actual: '$result2'"
    }

    # Test case 3: No occurrences
    $result3 = Replace-HelloWithWorld -s "no replacement here"
    $expected3 = "no replacement here"
    if ($result3 -ne $expected3) {
        throw "Test 3 failed. Expected: '$expected3', Actual: '$result3'"
    }

    # Test case 4: Adjacent occurrences
    $result4 = Replace-HelloWithWorld -s "hellohello"
    $expected4 = "worldworld"
    if ($result4 -ne $expected4) {
        throw "Test 4 failed. Expected: '$expected4', Actual: '$result4'"
    }

    Write-Output "All tests passed successfully"
}

Test-ReplaceHelloWithWorld

code:
<#
.SYNOPSIS
    Manages file storage operations for users, including UPLOAD and TRANSFER operations.
.DESCRIPTION
    This function processes a series of file operations (UPLOAD and TRANSFER) for multiple users,
    enforcing storage limits for each user. It updates the current storage usage accordingly.
.PARAMETER n
    The number of users.
.PARAMETER m
    The number of operations to process.
.PARAMETER storageLimits
    An array of storage limits for each user.
.PARAMETER operations
    An array of operations to process, each as a string in the format "UPLOAD user_id file_size" or "TRANSFER user_id1 user_id2 file_size".
.OUTPUTS
    An array of integers representing the current storage usage for each user after processing all operations.
#>
function Manage-Files {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int]$n,
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int]$m,
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int[]]$storageLimits,
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [string[]]$operations
    )

    $currentStorage = New-Object int[] $n

    foreach ($op in $operations) {
        $parts = $op -split ' '
        if ($parts[0] -eq "UPLOAD") {
            $userId = [int]$parts[1] - 1
            $fileSize = [int]$parts[2]
            if ($currentStorage[$userId] + $fileSize -le $storageLimits[$userId]) {
                $currentStorage[$userId] += $fileSize
            }
        }
        elseif ($parts[0] -eq "TRANSFER") {
            $userId1 = [int]$parts[1] - 1
            $userId2 = [int]$parts[2] - 1
            $fileSize = [int]$parts[3]
            if ($currentStorage[$userId1] -ge $fileSize -and $currentStorage[$userId2] + $fileSize -le $storageLimits[$userId2]) {
                $currentStorage[$userId1] -= $fileSize
                $currentStorage[$userId2] += $fileSize
            }
        }
    }

    return $currentStorage
}

<#
.SYNOPSIS
    Manages file storage operations for users, including UPLOAD and TRANSFER operations.
.DESCRIPTION
    This function processes a series of file operations (UPLOAD and TRANSFER) for multiple users,

.PARAMETER n
    The number of users.
.PARAMETER m
    The number of operations to process.
.PARAMETER storageLimits
    An array of storage limits for each user.
.PARAMETER operations
    An array of operations to process, each as a string in the format "UPLOAD user_id file_size" or "TRANSFER user_id1 user_id2 file_size".
.OUTPUTS
    An array of integers representing the current storage usage for each user after processing all operations.
#>
function Manage-Files {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int]$n,
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int]$m,
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int[]]$storageLimits,
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [string[]]$operations
    )

    $currentStorage = New-Object int[] $n

    foreach ($op in $operations) {
        $parts = $op -split ' '
        if ($parts[0] -eq "UPLOAD") {
            $userId = [int]$parts[1] - 1
            $fileSize = [int]$parts[2]
            if ($currentStorage[$userId] + $fileSize -le $storageLimits[$userId]) {
                $currentStorage[$userId] += $fileSize
            }
        }
        elseif ($parts[0] -eq "TRANSFER") {
            $userId1 = [int]$parts[1] - 1
            $userId2 = [int]$parts[2] - 1
            $fileSize = [int]$parts[3]
            if ($currentStorage[$userId1] -ge $fileSize -and $currentStorage[$userId2] + $fileSize -le $storageLimits[$userId2]) {
                $currentStorage[$userId1] -= $fileSize
                $currentStorage[$userId2] += $fileSize
            }
        }
    }

    return $currentStorage
}
function Compare-Arrays {
    param($a, $b)
    
    if ($a.Count -ne $b.Count) {
        return $false
    }
    
    for ($i = 0; $i -lt $a.Count; $i++) {
        if ($a[$i] -ne $b[$i]) {
            return $false
        }
    }
    
    return $true
}

function Test-ManageFiles {
    # Test Case 1
    $result1 = Manage-Files -n 3 -m 4 -storageLimits @(100, 200, 300) -operations @(
        "UPLOAD 1 50",
        "UPLOAD 2 100",
        "TRANSFER 1 2 30",
        "UPLOAD 3 200"
    )
    $expected1 = @(20, 130, 200)
    if (-not (Compare-Arrays $result1 $expected1)) {
        throw "Test Case 1 failed. Expected: $($expected1 -join ', '), Actual: $($result1 -join ', ')"
    }

    # Test Case 2
    $result2 = Manage-Files -n 2 -m 3 -storageLimits @(150, 150) -operations @(
        "UPLOAD 1 100",
        "TRANSFER 1 2 50",
        "UPLOAD 2 100"
    )
    $expected2 = @(50, 150)
    if (-not (Compare-Arrays $result2 $expected2)) {
        throw "Test Case 2 failed. Expected: $($expected2 -join ', '), Actual: $($result2 -join ', ')"
    }

    # Test Case 3
    $result3 = Manage-Files -n 1 -m 2 -storageLimits @(100) -operations @(
        "UPLOAD 1 50",
        "UPLOAD 1 60"
    )
    $expected3 = @(50)
    if (-not (Compare-Arrays $result3 $expected3)) {
        throw "Test Case 3 failed. Expected: $($expected3 -join ', '), Actual: $($result3 -join ', ')"
    }

    Write-Output "All test cases passed successfully"
}

Test-ManageFiles

# PowerShell Solution for Seller Price Filtering

<#
.SYNOPSIS
    Filters sellers based on whether they have any product priced below a specified threshold value.
.DESCRIPTION
    This script contains functions to process seller price data and identify which sellers have at least one product priced below a given threshold.
#>

function Get-SellersBelowThreshold {
    <#
    .SYNOPSIS
        Identifies sellers with at least one product priced below a specified threshold.
    .DESCRIPTION
        Takes an array of seller price lists and a threshold value, then returns the indices (1-based) of sellers who have at least one product priced below the threshold.
    .PARAMETER Sellers
        Array of arrays containing each seller's product prices.
    .PARAMETER Threshold
        The price threshold to compare against.
    .EXAMPLE
        Get-SellersBelowThreshold -Sellers @(@(50000), @(20000, 60000), @(10000, 70000, 190000)) -Threshold 50000
        Returns @(2, 3) as these sellers have products below 50000.
    #>
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [array]$Sellers,
        
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int]$Threshold
    )

    $result = @()
    for ($idx = 0; $idx -lt $Sellers.Count; $idx++) {
        $prices = $Sellers[$idx]
        $canDeal = $false
        
        foreach ($price in $prices) {
            if ($price -lt $Threshold) {
                $canDeal = $true
                break
            }
        }
        
        if ($canDeal) {
            $result += $idx + 1  # Using 1-based indexing
        }
    }

    return $result
}

function Format-SellerResults {
    <#
    .SYNOPSIS
        Formats the results of seller filtering according to the specified output format.
    .DESCRIPTION
        Takes the count and list of qualifying sellers and formats them according to the problem requirements.
    .PARAMETER Result
        Array of 1-based seller indices that meet the criteria.
    #>
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [array]$Result
    )

    if ($Result.Count -eq 0) {
        Write-Output "0"
    }
    else {
        Write-Output $Result.Count
        Write-Output ($Result -join ' ')
    }
}

<#
.SYNOPSIS
    Calculates the number of distinct Happy Chains of a given length.
.DESCRIPTION
    A Happy Chain is defined as a sequence of letters where no two adjacent letters are the same.
    For a chain of length n, the first letter can be any of 26 letters, and each subsequent letter
    can be any of the remaining 25 letters (different from the previous one).
.NOTES
    For n <= 0, the function returns 0 as there are no valid chains of non-positive length.
#>
function Get-HappyChainsCount {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int]$Length
    )

    if ($Length -le 0) {
        return 0
    }

    $totalChains = 26
    for ($i = 1; $i -lt $Length; $i++) {
        $totalChains *= 25
    }

    return $totalChains
}

    Calculates the number of distinct Happy Chains of a given length.

    A Happy Chain is defined as a sequence of letters where no two adjacent letters are the same.
    For a chain of length n, the first letter can be any of 26 letters, and each subsequent letter
    can be any of the remaining 25 letters (different from the previous one).
.NOTES
    For n <= 0, the function returns 0 as there are no valid chains of non-positive length.
#>
function Get-HappyChainsCount {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int]$Length
    )

    if ($Length -le 0) {
        return 0
    }

    $totalChains = 26
    for ($i = 1; $i -lt $Length; $i++) {
        $totalChains *= 25
    }

    return $totalChains
}
function Test-HappyChainsCount {
    $testCases = @(
        @{Length = 1; Expected = 26; Description = "Minimum valid length"},
        @{Length = 2; Expected = 650; Description = "Two-letter chains"},
        @{Length = 3; Expected = 16250; Description = "Three-letter chains"},
        @{Length = 0; Expected = 0; Description = "Zero length (invalid)"},
        @{Length = -1; Expected = 0; Description = "Negative length (invalid)"},
        @{Length = 5; Expected = 10156250; Description = "Five-letter chains"}
    )

    foreach ($testCase in $testCases) {
        $result = Get-HappyChainsCount -Length $testCase.Length
        if ($result -ne $testCase.Expected) {
            throw "Test failed for $($testCase.Description). Expected $($testCase.Expected), but got $result"
        }
        Write-Output "Test passed: $($testCase.Description)"
    }
}

<#
.SYNOPSIS
    Finds the element that appears exactly once in an array where all other elements appear exactly twice.
.DESCRIPTION
    This function uses the XOR bitwise operation to find the unique element in an array. 
    XORing all elements cancels out the duplicates, leaving only the unique element.
.PARAMETER arr
    The input array of integers where all elements except one appear exactly twice.
.EXAMPLE
    Find-UniqueElement -arr @(2, 3, 4, 3, 2)
    Returns 4, as it's the only unique element in the array.
#>
function Find-UniqueElement {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int[]]$arr
    )

    $uniqueElement = 0
    foreach ($element in $arr) {
        $uniqueElement = $uniqueElement -bxor $element
    }
    return $uniqueElement
}

<#
.SYNOPSIS
    Checks if the product of two integers is a palindrome.

.DESCRIPTION
    This function takes two positive integers, calculates their product, and checks if the product is a palindrome.
    A palindrome is a number that reads the same backward as forward.

.PARAMETER a
    The first positive integer.

.PARAMETER b
    The second positive integer.

.OUTPUTS
    System.Boolean
    Returns $true if the product is a palindrome, otherwise $false.
#>
function Test-PalindromicProduct {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int]$a,
        
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int]$b
    )

    $product = $a * $b
    $stringProduct = $product.ToString()
    $reversedString = -join ($stringProduct[-1..-($stringProduct.Length)])
    
    return $stringProduct -eq $reversedString
}

function Test-PalindromicProductTests {
    # Test case 1: 11 * 11 = 121 (palindrome)
    $result1 = Test-PalindromicProduct -a 11 -b 11
    if (-not $result1) {
        throw "Test 1 failed: Expected True for 11 * 11"
    }

    # Test case 2: 10 * 10 = 100 (not a palindrome)
    $result2 = Test-PalindromicProduct -a 10 -b 10
    if ($result2) {
        throw "Test 2 failed: Expected False for 10 * 10"
    }

    # Test case 3: 12 * 21 = 252 (palindrome)
    $result3 = Test-PalindromicProduct -a 12 -b 21
    if (-not $result3) {
        throw "Test 3 failed: Expected True for 12 * 21"
    }

    # Test case 4: 15 * 16 = 240 (not a palindrome)
    $result4 = Test-PalindromicProduct -a 15 -b 16
    if ($result4) {
        throw "Test 4 failed: Expected False for 15 * 16"
    }

    Write-Output "All tests passed successfully"
}

Test-PalindromicProductTests

<#
.SYNOPSIS
    Determines whether each student can see the board based on their heights.
.DESCRIPTION
    This function checks each student's height in sequence and determines if they can see the board.
    A student can see the board if they are taller than all the students in front of them.
.PARAMETER n
    The number of students.
.PARAMETER heights
    An array of integers representing the heights of the students.
.OUTPUTS
    An array of booleans where each element indicates whether the corresponding student can see the board.
#>
function Can-SeeBoard {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int]$n,
        
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int[]]$heights
    )

    $result = @()
    $max_height_so_far = 0
    
    foreach ($height in $heights) {
        if ($height -gt $max_height_so_far) {
            $result += $true
            $max_height_so_far = $height
        } else {
            $result += $false
        }
    }
    
    return $result
}

.SYNOPSIS
    Determines whether each student can see the board based on their heights.
.DESCRIPTION
    This function checks each student's height in sequence and determines if they can see the board.
    A student can see the board if they are taller than all the students in front of them.
.PARAMETER n
    The number of students.
.PARAMETER heights
    An array of integers representing the heights of the students.
.OUTPUTS
    An array of booleans where each element indicates whether the corresponding student can see the board.
#>
function Can-SeeBoard {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int]$n,
        
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int[]]$heights
    )

    $result = @()
    $max_height_so_far = 0
    
    foreach ($height in $heights) {
        if ($height -gt $max_height_so_far) {
            $result += $true
            $max_height_so_far = $height
        } else {
            $result += $false
        }
    }
    
    return $result
}
function Compare-Arrays {
    param($a, $b)
    
    if ($a.Count -ne $b.Count) {
        return $false
    }
    
    for ($i = 0; $i -lt $a.Count; $i++) {
        if ($a[$i] -ne $b[$i]) {
            return $false
        }
    }
    
    return $true
}

function Test-CanSeeBoard {
    # Test case 1
    $result1 = Can-SeeBoard -n 5 -heights @(4, 3, 5, 2, 6)
    $expected1 = @($true, $false, $true, $false, $true)
    if (-not (Compare-Arrays $result1 $expected1)) {
        throw "Test case 1 failed"
    }

    # Test case 2
    $result2 = Can-SeeBoard -n 3 -heights @(1, 2, 3)
    $expected2 = @($true, $true, $true)
    if (-not (Compare-Arrays $result2 $expected2)) {
        throw "Test case 2 failed"
    }

    # Test case 3
    $result3 = Can-SeeBoard -n 4 -heights @(5, 5, 5, 5)
    $expected3 = @($true, $false, $false, $false)
    if (-not (Compare-Arrays $result3 $expected3)) {
        throw "Test case 3 failed"
    }

    # Test case 4
    $result4 = Can-SeeBoard -n 1 -heights @(1)
    $expected4 = @($true)
    if (-not (Compare-Arrays $result4 $expected4)) {
        throw "Test case 4 failed"
    }

    Write-Output "All test cases passed"
}

Test-CanSeeBoard

<#
.SYNOPSIS
    Returns the sound made by the first animal found in the sentence.

.DESCRIPTION
    This function checks each word in the input sentence against a predefined list of animals and their sounds.
    If an animal is found, it returns the corresponding sound; otherwise, it returns $null.

.PARAMETER Sentence
    The input sentence containing words to be checked for animal names.

.OUTPUTS
    System.String
    Returns the sound of the first animal found in the sentence or $null if no animal is found.
#>
function Get-AnimalSound {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [string]$Sentence
    )

    $animalSounds = @{
        "dog" = "woof"
        "cat" = "meow"
        "cow" = "moo"
        "pig" = "oink"
        "sheep" = "baa"
        "horse" = "neigh"
    }

    $words = $Sentence -split '\s+'
    foreach ($word in $words) {
        $lowerWord = $word.ToLower()
        if ($animalSounds.ContainsKey($lowerWord)) {
            return $animalSounds[$lowerWord]
        }
    }
    return $null
}

code:
<#
.SYNOPSIS
    Solves for x in the equation (c*x + 1)*ln(x) = ln(P) using binary search.
.DESCRIPTION
    This script implements a binary search algorithm to solve for x in the equation (c*x + 1)*ln(x) = ln(P).
    It reads multiple test cases, each consisting of P and c values, and computes the solution x for each case.
    The solution is printed with 6 decimal places precision.
#>

function Solve-Equation {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory=$true)]
        [int]$P,
        
        [Parameter(Mandatory=$true)]
        [int]$c
    )

    if ($P -eq 1) {
        return 1.000000
    }

    $target = [Math]::Log($P)
    $low = 1.0
    $high = 1.0

    # Find the upper bound for binary search
    while ($true) {
        $val = ($c * $high + 1) * [Math]::Log($high)
        if ($val -gt $target) {
            break
        }
        $high *= 2
    }

    # Perform binary search with 100 iterations for precision
    for ($i = 0; $i -lt 100; $i++) {
        $mid = ($low + $high) / 2
        $currentVal = ($c * $mid + 1) * [Math]::Log($mid)
        
        if ($currentVal -lt $target) {
            $low = $mid
        }
        else {
            $high = $mid
        }
    }

    $result = ($low + $high) / 2
    return [math]::Round($result, 6)
}

# PowerShell Code for Decoding Rotated Messages

<#
.SYNOPSIS
    Decodes a message that was encoded by rotating each letter a specified number of positions.
.DESCRIPTION
    This script contains functions to decode messages encoded with a simple rotation cipher.
    The core function rotates letters backward in the alphabet by a specified number of positions.
    Spaces in the message are left unchanged.
#>

function Decode-Message {
    <#
    .SYNOPSIS
        Decodes a message that was encoded with letter rotation.
    .DESCRIPTION
        Takes an encoded message and rotates each letter backward by 'n' positions in the alphabet.
        Spaces in the message are preserved.
    .PARAMETER n
        The number of positions each letter was rotated during encoding
    .PARAMETER encoded
        The encoded message to decode (lowercase letters and spaces only)
    .EXAMPLE
        Decode-Message -n 3 -encoded "khoor"
        Returns "hello"
    #>
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int]$n,
        
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [string]$encoded
    )

    $decodedChars = @()
    foreach ($char in $encoded.ToCharArray()) {
        if ($char -eq ' ') {
            $decodedChars += ' '
        }
        else {
            # Calculate the decoded character position
            $originalPos = ([int][char]$char - [int][char]'a' - $n) % 26
            # Handle negative positions by wrapping around
            if ($originalPos -lt 0) {
                $originalPos += 26
            }
            $decodedChar = [char]($originalPos + [int][char]'a')
            $decodedChars += $decodedChar
        }
    }
    return -join $decodedChars
}

function Process-TestCases {
    <#
    .SYNOPSIS
        Processes multiple test cases for message decoding.
    .DESCRIPTION
        Takes an array of test cases (each containing rotation count and encoded message)
        and returns the decoded messages for all test cases.
    .PARAMETER testCases
        Array of hashtables with 'n' and 'message' keys representing test cases
    .EXAMPLE
        Process-TestCases -testCases @(@{n=3; message="khoor"}, @{n=1; message="ifmmp"})
        Returns @("hello", "hello")
    #>
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [array]$testCases
    )

    $results = @()
    foreach ($testCase in $testCases) {
        $results += Decode-Message -n $testCase.n -encoded $testCase.message
    }
    return $results
}

function Test-DecodeMessage {

    $result1 = Decode-Message -n 3 -encoded "khoor zruog"
    $expected1 = "hello world"
    if ($result1 -ne $expected1) {

    $result2 = Decode-Message -n 1 -encoded "ifmmp xpsme"

    $result3 = Decode-Message -n 13 -encoded "uryyb jbeyq"

    if ($result3 -ne $expected3) {
        throw "Test 3 failed: Expected '$expected3', got '$result3'"
    }

    $result4 = Decode-Message -n 25 -encoded "bmjs jt zpv"
    $expected4 = "cnkt ku aqw"
    if ($result4 -ne $expected4) {

    }

    # Test case 5: No rotation
    $result5 = Decode-Message -n 0 -encoded "no rotation"
    $expected5 = "no rotation"
    if ($result5 -ne $expected5) {
        throw "Test 5 failed: Expected '$expected5', got '$result5'"
    }

    # Batch processing test
    $testCases = @(
        @{n = 3; message = "khoor zruog"},
        @{n = 1; message = "ifmmp xpsme"},
        @{n = 13; message = "uryyb jbeyq"},
        @{n = 25; message = "bmjs jt zpv"},
        @{n = 0; message = "no rotation"}
    )
    $batchResults = Process-TestCases -testCases $testCases
    $expectedBatchResults = @("hello world", "hello world", "hello world", "cnkt ku aqw", "no rotation")
    
    for ($i = 0; $i -lt $batchResults.Count; $i++) {
        if ($batchResults[$i] -ne $expectedBatchResults[$i]) {
            throw "Batch test case $($i+1) failed: Expected '$($expectedBatchResults[$i])', got '$($batchResults[$i])'"
        }
    }

    Write-Output "All tests passed successfully"
}

Test-DecodeMessage

code:
<#
.SYNOPSIS
    Sorts an array of integers using the optimized Gnome Sort algorithm.
.DESCRIPTION
    This function implements the optimized Gnome Sort algorithm, which is a variation of the standard Gnome Sort.
    It works by comparing the current element with the previous one and swapping them if they are in the wrong order.
    The optimization comes from not moving back to the start of the array after each swap, but rather just one step back.
.PARAMETER Arr
    The array of integers to be sorted.
.OUTPUTS
    Returns the sorted array.
#>
function Optimized-GnomeSort {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int[]]$Arr
    )

    $n = $Arr.Length
    $index = 0

    while ($index -lt $n) {
        if ($index -eq 0 -or $Arr[$index] -ge $Arr[$index - 1]) {
            $index++
        } else {
            # Swap the elements
            $temp = $Arr[$index]
            $Arr[$index] = $Arr[$index - 1]
            $Arr[$index - 1] = $temp

            $index--
        }
    }

    return $Arr
}

function Compare-Arrays {
    param($a, $b)
    
    if ($a.Count -ne $b.Count) {
        return $false
    }
    
    for ($i = 0; $i -lt $a.Count; $i++) {
        if ($a[$i] -ne $b[$i]) {
            return $false
        }
    }
    
    return $true
}

            return $false
        }
    }
    
    return $true
}
function Test-OptimizedGnomeSort {
    $testCases = @(
        @{
            Input = @(3, 1, 4, 1, 5, 9, 2, 6, 5)
            Expected = @(1, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 5, 6, 9)
        },
        @{
            Input = @(9, 8, 7, 6, 5, 4, 3, 2, 1)
            Expected = @(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9)
        },
        @{
            Input = @(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9)
            Expected = @(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9)
        },
        @{
            Input = @(5, -3, 0, 12, -7, 8)
            Expected = @(-7, -3, 0, 5, 8, 12)
        },
        @{
            Input = @()
            Expected = @()
        },
        @{
            Input = @(42)
            Expected = @(42)
        }
    )

    foreach ($testCase in $testCases) {
        $result = Optimized-GnomeSort -Arr $testCase.Input
        if (-not (Compare-Arrays $result $testCase.Expected)) {
            throw "Test failed for input: $($testCase.Input -join ', '). Expected: $($testCase.Expected -join ', '), but got: $($result -join ', ')"
        }
    }

    Write-Output "All tests passed successfully"
}

<#
.SYNOPSIS
    Determines the mode of an array of numbers.
.DESCRIPTION
    This function calculates the mode(s) of an array of numbers. In case of a tie for mode,
    it returns all numbers that tie for the highest frequency.
.PARAMETER Numbers
    An array of numbers for which the mode(s) should be calculated.
.EXAMPLE
    Find-Mode -Numbers @(1, 2, 2, 3, 3)
    Returns @(2, 3) because both numbers appear twice.
#>
function Find-Mode {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [double[]]$Numbers
    )

    if ($Numbers.Count -eq 0) {
        return @()
    }

    # Create a hashtable to count occurrences of each number
    $numberCounts = @{}
    foreach ($number in $Numbers) {
        if ($numberCounts.ContainsKey($number)) {
            $numberCounts[$number]++
        } else {
            $numberCounts[$number] = 1
        }
    }

    # Find the maximum count
    $maxCount = ($numberCounts.Values | Measure-Object -Maximum).Maximum

    # Collect all numbers that have the maximum count
    $modes = @()
    foreach ($key in $numberCounts.Keys) {
        if ($numberCounts[$key] -eq $maxCount) {
            $modes += $key
        }
    }

    return $modes
}

function Compare-Arrays {
    param($a, $b)
    
    if ($a.Count -ne $b.Count) {
        return $false
    }
    
    for ($i = 0; $i -lt $a.Count; $i++) {
        if ($a[$i] -ne $b[$i]) {
            return $false
        }
    }
    
    return $true
}

function Test-FindMode {
    # Test case 1: Multiple modes
    $result1 = Find-Mode -Numbers @(1, 2, 2, 3, 3)
    $expected1 = @(2, 3)
    if (-not (Compare-Arrays ($result1 | Sort-Object) ($expected1 | Sort-Object))) {
        throw "Test 1 failed"
    }

    # Test case 2: Single mode
    $result2 = Find-Mode -Numbers @(1, 1, 2, 3, 4)
    $expected2 = @(1)
    if (-not (Compare-Arrays $result2 $expected2)) {

    }

    # Test case 3: All elements the same
    $result3 = Find-Mode -Numbers @(5, 5, 5, 5, 5)
    $expected3 = @(5)
    if (-not (Compare-Arrays $result3 $expected3)) {
        throw "Test 3 failed"
    }

    # Test case 4: Empty array
    $result4 = Find-Mode -Numbers @()
    $expected4 = @()
    if (-not (Compare-Arrays $result4 $expected4)) {
        throw "Test 4 failed"
    }

    # Test case 5: No mode (all unique)
    $result5 = Find-Mode -Numbers @(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)
    $expected5 = @(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)
    if (-not (Compare-Arrays ($result5 | Sort-Object) ($expected5 | Sort-Object))) {

    }

    Write-Output "All tests passed"
}

<#
.SYNOPSIS
    Counts the minimum number of adjacent swaps needed to sort an array using bubble sort algorithm.
.DESCRIPTION
    This function implements the bubble sort algorithm to count the number of adjacent swaps required
    to sort an array in ascending order. The function processes multiple test cases and returns the
    swap counts for each case.
.PARAMETER TestCases
    An array of test cases, where each test case is an array of integers to be sorted.
.OUTPUTS
    An array of integers representing the minimum number of adjacent swaps needed for each test case.
#>
function Count-MinimumAdjacentSwaps {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [array[]]$TestCases
    )

    $results = @()

    foreach ($case in $TestCases) {
        $arr = $case
        $n = $arr.Count
        $swaps = 0
        
        for ($i = 0; $i -lt $n; $i++) {
            for ($j = 0; $j -lt ($n - 1); $j++) {
                if ($arr[$j] -gt $arr[$j + 1]) {
                    # Swap adjacent elements
                    $temp = $arr[$j]
                    $arr[$j] = $arr[$j + 1]
                    $arr[$j + 1] = $temp
                    $swaps++
                }
            }
        }
        $results += $swaps
    }
    
    return $results
}

    This function implements the bubble sort algorithm to count the number of adjacent swaps required
    to sort an array in ascending order. The function processes multiple test cases and returns the
    swap counts for each case.
.PARAMETER TestCases
    An array of test cases, where each test case is an array of integers to be sorted.
.OUTPUTS
    An array of integers representing the minimum number of adjacent swaps needed for each test case.
#>
function Count-MinimumAdjacentSwaps {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [array[]]$TestCases
    )

    $results = @()

    foreach ($case in $TestCases) {
        $arr = $case
        $n = $arr.Count
        $swaps = 0
        
        for ($i = 0; $i -lt $n; $i++) {
            for ($j = 0; $j -lt ($n - 1); $j++) {
                if ($arr[$j] -gt $arr[$j + 1]) {

                    $temp = $arr[$j]
                    $arr[$j] = $arr[$j + 1]

                    $swaps++
                }
            }
        }
        $results += $swaps
    }
    
    return $results
}
function Test-CountMinimumAdjacentSwaps {
    $testCases = @(
        @(1, 2, 3, 4)    # Already sorted - should require 0 swaps
        @(4, 3, 2, 1)    # Reverse order - should require maximum swaps
        @(1, 3, 2, 4)    # Partially sorted
        @(5, 1, 4, 2, 3) # Random order
        @(1, 1, 1, 1)    # All elements equal
    )

    $expectedResults = @(
        0   # Test Case 1
        6   # Test Case 2 (4,3,2,1 requires 3+2+1=6 swaps)
        1   # Test Case 3 (swap 3 and 2)
        5   # Test Case 4
        0   # Test Case 5
    )

    $results = Count-MinimumAdjacentSwaps -TestCases $testCases

    for ($i = 0; $i -lt $testCases.Count; $i++) {
        if ($results[$i] -ne $expectedResults[$i]) {
            throw "Test Case $($i+1) failed. Expected $($expectedResults[$i]) but got $($results[$i]) for array $($testCases[$i] -join ', ')"
        }
    }

    Write-Output "All test cases passed successfully"
}

code:
<#
.SYNOPSIS
    Determines if a one-to-one mapping exists between the characters of two strings.

.DESCRIPTION
    This function checks if there is a bijective mapping (one-to-one and onto) between the characters 
    of the first string (s1) and the characters of the second string (s2). The mapping must be consistent 
    for all occurrences of each character in both strings.

.PARAMETER s1
    The first string to compare.

.PARAMETER s2
    The second string to compare.

.OUTPUTS
    Boolean
    Returns $true if a valid one-to-one morphism exists between s1 and s2, otherwise returns $false.
#>
function Test-CharacterMorphism {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [string]$s1,

        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [string]$s2
    )

    # A one-to-one morphism can exist only if both strings have the same length
    if ($s1.Length -ne $s2.Length) {
        return $false
    }

    $mappingS1ToS2 = @{}
    $mappingS2ToS1 = @{}

    for ($i = 0; $i -lt $s1.Length; $i++) {
        $char1 = $s1[$i]
        $char2 = $s2[$i]

        # Check mapping from s1 to s2
        if ($mappingS1ToS2.ContainsKey($char1)) {
            if ($mappingS1ToS2[$char1] -ne $char2) {
                return $false
            }
        } else {
            $mappingS1ToS2[$char1] = $char2
        }

        # Check mapping from s2 to s1
        if ($mappingS2ToS1.ContainsKey($char2)) {
            if ($mappingS2ToS1[$char2] -ne $char1) {
                return $false
            }
        } else {
            $mappingS2ToS1[$char2] = $char1
        }
    }

    return $true
}

<#
.SYNOPSIS
    Calculates the maximum sum based on two lists of integers (ones and twos).

.DESCRIPTION
    This script reads two lists of integers, sorts them, and then calculates the maximum sum
    based on a specific formula involving counts from both lists.
#>

function Get-MaxSum {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int[]]$Ones,
        
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int[]]$Twos
    )

    # Sort the input arrays
    $sortedOnes = $Ones | Sort-Object
    $sortedTwos = $Twos | Sort-Object

    $maxSum = [Math]::Pow(10, 9)  # Base case: take nothing, only initial.

    $m = $sortedOnes.Count
    $t = $sortedTwos.Count

    for ($k = 0; $k -le $m; $k++) {
        if ($k -eq 0) {
            $xMax = 0
        } else {
            $xMax = $sortedOnes[$k - 1]
        }

        # Find the first index in twos greater than xMax
        $idx = 0
        while ($idx -lt $t -and $sortedTwos[$idx] -le $xMax) {
            $idx++
        }
        $count = $t - $idx

        $currentSum = [Math]::Pow(10, 9) + $k + 2 * $count
        if ($currentSum -gt $maxSum) {
            $maxSum = $currentSum
        }
    }

    return $maxSum
}

code:
<#
.SYNOPSIS
    Groups consecutive repeating characters in a string with their counts.
.DESCRIPTION
    This function takes a string and returns a list of grouped characters with their counts in the format 'char-count'.
    It processes the string recursively, grouping consecutive identical characters.
.PARAMETER s
    The input string to process
.PARAMETER acc
    The accumulator list used for recursion (not meant to be provided by the caller)
#>
function Group-String {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [string]$s,
        
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $false)]
        [System.Collections.Generic.List[string]]$acc = $null
    )

    # Initialize accumulator if not provided
    if ($null -eq $acc) {
        $acc = [System.Collections.Generic.List[string]]::new()
    }

    # Base case: empty string
    if ([string]::IsNullOrEmpty($s)) {
        return $acc
    }

    $char = $s[0]
    $count = 1

    # Count consecutive characters
    while ($count -lt $s.Length -and $s[$count] -eq $char) {
        $count++
    }

    # Add the grouped character and count to the accumulator
    $acc.Add("$char-$count")

    # Recursive call with remaining string
    return Group-String -s $s.Substring($count) -acc $acc
}

function Compare-StringLists {
    param(
        [System.Collections.Generic.List[string]]$a,
        [System.Collections.Generic.List[string]]$b
    )

    if ($a.Count -ne $b.Count) {
        return $false
    }

    for ($i = 0; $i -lt $a.Count; $i++) {
        if ($a[$i] -ne $b[$i]) {
            return $false
        }
    }

    return $true
}

function Test-GroupString {
    # Test case 1: Basic grouping
    $result1 = Group-String -s "aaabbbcc"
    $expected1 = [System.Collections.Generic.List[string]]::new()
    $expected1.AddRange(@("a-3", "b-3", "c-2"))
    if (-not (Compare-StringLists $result1 $expected1)) {
        throw "Test 1 failed: Expected 'a-3, b-3, c-2' but got '$($result1 -join ', ')'"
    }

    # Test case 2: Mixed characters
    $result2 = Group-String -s "hello"
    $expected2 = [System.Collections.Generic.List[string]]::new()
    $expected2.AddRange(@("h-1", "e-1", "l-2", "o-1"))
    if (-not (Compare-StringLists $result2 $expected2)) {
        throw "Test 2 failed: Expected 'h-1, e-1, l-2, o-1' but got '$($result2 -join ', ')'"
    }

    # Test case 3: Complex pattern
    $result3 = Group-String -s "mississippi"
    $expected3 = [System.Collections.Generic.List[string]]::new()
    $expected3.AddRange(@("m-1", "i-1", "s-2", "i-1", "s-2", "i-1", "p-2", "i-1"))
    if (-not (Compare-StringLists $result3 $expected3)) {
        throw "Test 3 failed: Expected 'm-1, i-1, s-2, i-1, s-2, i-1, p-2, i-1' but got '$($result3 -join ', ')'"
    }

    # Test case 4: Single character
    $result4 = Group-String -s "a"
    $expected4 = [System.Collections.Generic.List[string]]::new()
    $expected4.Add("a-1")
    if (-not (Compare-StringLists $result4 $expected4)) {
        throw "Test 4 failed: Expected 'a-1' but got '$($result4 -join ', ')'"
    }

    # Test case 5: Empty string
    $result5 = Group-String -s ""
    $expected5 = [System.Collections.Generic.List[string]]::new()
    if (-not (Compare-StringLists $result5 $expected5)) {
        throw "Test 5 failed: Expected empty list but got '$($result5 -join ', ')'"
    }

    # Test case 6: All same characters
    $result6 = Group-String -s "xxxxxx"
    $expected6 = [System.Collections.Generic.List[string]]::new()
    $expected6.Add("x-6")
    if (-not (Compare-StringLists $result6 $expected6)) {
        throw "Test 6 failed: Expected 'x-6' but got '$($result6 -join ', ')'"
    }

    Write-Output "All tests passed successfully"
}

code:
<#
.SYNOPSIS
    Calculates the number of possible paths in a grid from start to end position within given time steps.
.DESCRIPTION
    This script models movement on a grid where you can move up, down, left, or right at each time step.
    It counts how many distinct paths exist from the start position to the end position in exactly T steps,
    avoiding blocked cells marked with '#'.
#>

function Count-GridPaths {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory=$true)]
        [int]$n,  # Number of rows in grid
        
        [Parameter(Mandatory=$true)]
        [int]$m,  # Number of columns in grid
        
        [Parameter(Mandatory=$true)]
        [int]$T,  # Number of time steps
        
        [Parameter(Mandatory=$true)]
        [string[]]$grid,  # Grid representation (each string is a row)
        
        [Parameter(Mandatory=$true)]
        [int]$start_r,  # Start row (0-based)
        
        [Parameter(Mandatory=$true)]
        [int]$start_c,  # Start column (0-based)
        
        [Parameter(Mandatory=$true)]
        [int]$end_r,  # End row (0-based)
        
        [Parameter(Mandatory=$true)]
        [int]$end_c  # End column (0-based)
    )

    # Check if start or end positions are blocked
    if ($grid[$start_r][$start_c] -ne '.' -or $grid[$end_r][$end_c] -ne '.') {
        return 0
    }

    # Initialize previous DP array
    $prev_dp = New-Object 'int[][]' $n
    for ($i = 0; $i -lt $n; $i++) {
        $prev_dp[$i] = New-Object 'int[]' $m
    }
    $prev_dp[$start_r][$start_c] = 1

    # Directions: up, down, left, right
    $directions = @(
        @(-1, 0),  # up
        @(1, 0),   # down
        @(0, -1),  # left
        @(0, 1)    # right
    )

    for ($step = 0; $step -lt $T; $step++) {
        $curr_dp = New-Object 'int[][]' $n
        for ($i = 0; $i -lt $n; $i++) {
            $curr_dp[$i] = New-Object 'int[]' $m
        }

        for ($i = 0; $i -lt $n; $i++) {
            for ($j = 0; $j -lt $m; $j++) {
                if ($grid[$i][$j] -eq '.') {
                    $total = 0
                    foreach ($dir in $directions) {
                        $dx, $dy = $dir[0], $dir[1]
                        $ni = $i + $dx
                        $nj = $j + $dy
                        if ($ni -ge 0 -and $ni -lt $n -and $nj -ge 0 -and $nj -lt $m) {
                            $total += $prev_dp[$ni][$nj]
                        }
                    }
                    $curr_dp[$i][$j] = $total
                }
                else {
                    $curr_dp[$i][$j] = 0
                }
            }
        }
        $prev_dp = $curr_dp
    }

    return $prev_dp[$end_r][$end_c]
}

function Test-CountGridPaths {

    if ($result1 -ne 2) {
        throw "Test case 1 failed: Expected 2, got $result1"
    }

    # Test case 2: 3x3 grid with obstacle and 2 steps
    $result2 = Count-GridPaths -n 3 -m 3 -T 2 -grid @("...", ".#.", "...") -start_r 0 -start_c 0 -end_r 2 -end_c 2
    if ($result2 -ne 0) {
        throw "Test case 2 failed: Expected 0, got $result2"
    }

    # Test case 3: Simple 2x2 grid with 1 step
    $result3 = Count-GridPaths -n 2 -m 2 -T 1 -grid @("..", "..") -start_r 0 -start_c 0 -end_r 0 -end_c 1
    if ($result3 -ne 1) {
        throw "Test case 3 failed: Expected 1, got $result3"
    }

    Write-Output "All test cases passed successfully"
}

code:
<#
.DESCRIPTION
Distributes n scrolls with power levels between l and r to m apprentices such that each apprentice 
gets the same number of scrolls and the difference between the maximum and minimum power levels 
in each group is minimized.

.PARAMETER n
Total number of scrolls

.PARAMETER m
Number of apprentices

.PARAMETER l
Minimum power level

.PARAMETER r
Maximum power level

.OUTPUTS
Returns an array of arrays representing the distribution of scrolls to each apprentice, 
or "Impossible" if distribution is not possible.
#>
function Distribute-Scrolls {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int]$n,
        
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int]$m,
        
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int]$l,
        
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int]$r
    )

    # Check if distribution is possible
    if ($n % $m -ne 0) {
        return "Impossible"
    }

    $scrollsPerApprentice = $n / $m
    $scrolls = $l..($l + $scrollsPerApprentice * $m - 1)

    $result = @()
    for ($i = 0; $i -lt $m; $i++) {
        $startIndex = $i * $scrollsPerApprentice
        $endIndex = ($i + 1) * $scrollsPerApprentice - 1
        $apprenticeScrolls = $scrolls[$startIndex..$endIndex]
        $result += ,$apprenticeScrolls
    }

    return $result
}

function Compare-Arrays {
    param($a, $b)

    if ($a.Count -ne $b.Count) {
        return $false
    }

    for ($i = 0; $i -lt $a.Count; $i++) {
        if ($a[$i] -ne $b[$i]) {
            return $false
        }
    }

    return $true
}

function Test-DistributeScrolls {
    # Test case 1: Valid distribution
    $result1 = Distribute-Scrolls -n 6 -m 2 -l 1 -r 10
    $expected1 = @(@(1, 2, 3), @(4, 5, 6))
    if (-not (Compare-Arrays $result1[0] $expected1[0]) -or -not (Compare-Arrays $result1[1] $expected1[1])) {
        throw "Test case 1 failed"
    }

    # Test case 2: Impossible distribution
    $result2 = Distribute-Scrolls -n 5 -m 2 -l 1 -r 10
    if ($result2 -ne "Impossible") {
        throw "Test case 2 failed"
    }

    # Test case 3: Valid distribution with more apprentices
    $result3 = Distribute-Scrolls -n 8 -m 4 -l 5 -r 20
    $expected3 = @(@(5, 6), @(7, 8), @(9, 10), @(11, 12))
    for ($i = 0; $i -lt $expected3.Count; $i++) {
        if (-not (Compare-Arrays $result3[$i] $expected3[$i])) {
            throw "Test case 3 failed"
        }
    }

    # Test case 4: Valid distribution with higher starting level
    $result4 = Distribute-Scrolls -n 9 -m 3 -l 10 -r 20
    $expected4 = @(@(10, 11, 12), @(13, 14, 15), @(16, 17, 18))
    for ($i = 0; $i -lt $expected4.Count; $i++) {
        if (-not (Compare-Arrays $result4[$i] $expected4[$i])) {
            throw "Test case 4 failed"
        }
    }

    Write-Output "All test cases passed"
}

code:
<#
.SYNOPSIS
    Processes numbers to count those that don't contain prime digits (2, 3, 5, 7) using a prefix sum array.
.DESCRIPTION
    This script precomputes a prefix sum array to efficiently answer range queries about numbers without prime digits.
    The solution involves two main parts:
    1. Preprocessing to mark numbers containing prime digits and build a prefix sum array
    2. Query processing to quickly answer count queries between ranges
#>

# Initialize global variables
$maxNum = 100000
$primeDigits = @('2', '3', '5', '7')
$prefix = @(0) * ($maxNum + 1)

<#
.SYNOPSIS
    Preprocesses numbers up to maxNum to identify those without prime digits and builds a prefix sum array.
.DESCRIPTION
    Creates a boolean array marking numbers that contain prime digits, then builds a prefix sum array
    for efficient range queries. The prefix array at index i contains the count of valid numbers from 1 to i.
#>
function Preprocess-Numbers {
    $valid = @($true) * ($maxNum + 1)
    
    for ($num = 1; $num -le $maxNum; $num++) {
        $s = $num.ToString()
        foreach ($c in $s.ToCharArray()) {
            if ($primeDigits -contains $c) {
                $valid[$num] = $false
                break
            }
        }
    }
    
    # Build prefix sum array
    $count = 0
    for ($i = 1; $i -le $maxNum; $i++) {
        if ($valid[$i]) {
            $count++
        }
        $prefix[$i] = $count
    }
}

<#
.SYNOPSIS
    Processes range queries to count numbers without prime digits between A and B.
.DESCRIPTION
    Uses the precomputed prefix sum array to quickly answer count queries.
    The result for range [A, B] is calculated as prefix[B] - prefix[A-1].
.PARAMETER A
    The lower bound of the range (inclusive)
.PARAMETER B
    The upper bound of the range (inclusive)
.OUTPUTS
    Returns the count of numbers between A and B (inclusive) that don't contain any prime digits
#>
function Get-CountWithoutPrimeDigits {
    param (
        [int]$A,
        [int]$B
    )
    
    if ($A -eq 0) {
        return $prefix[$B]
    }
    return $prefix[$B] - $prefix[$A - 1]
}

# Preprocess numbers when the script is loaded
Preprocess-Numbers

code:
# Find-MinRepositoriesToReachTarget determines the minimum number of repositories needed to reach or exceed the given target number of stars.
# The repositories are sorted in descending order by their star counts, and we accumulate stars until the target is met or exceeded.
# If the target cannot be reached with the given repositories, it returns -1.
function Find-MinRepositoriesToReachTarget {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int]$n,
        
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int[]]$starCounts,
        
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int]$target
    )

    # Sort the star counts in descending order
    $sortedStarCounts = $starCounts | Sort-Object -Descending

    $currentSum = 0
    for ($i = 0; $i -lt $n; $i++) {
        $currentSum += $sortedStarCounts[$i]
        if ($currentSum -ge $target) {
            return $i + 1
        }
    }

}

<#
.SYNOPSIS
    Adds a specified number of seconds to a given time in "HH:MM:SS" format.
.DESCRIPTION
    This function takes a time string in "HH:MM:SS" format and adds a specified number of seconds to it.
    The result is returned in the same "HH:MM:SS" format, properly handling overflow (e.g., wrapping around after 23:59:59).
.PARAMETER Time
    A string representing the time in "HH:MM:SS" format.
.PARAMETER Seconds
    The number of seconds to add to the given time.
.EXAMPLE
    Add-SecondsToTime -Time "12:30:45" -Seconds 30
    Returns "12:31:15"
#>
function Add-SecondsToTime {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [string]$Time,
        
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int]$Seconds
    )

    # Parse the input time
    $timeParts = $Time -split ':'
    $hh = [int]$timeParts[0]
    $mm = [int]$timeParts[1]
    $ss = [int]$timeParts[2]
    
    # Convert the total time to seconds
    $totalSeconds = $hh * 3600 + $mm * 60 + $ss + $Seconds
    
    # Calculate the new hours, minutes, and seconds
    $newHh = ($totalSeconds / 3600) % 24
    $totalSeconds = $totalSeconds % 3600
    $newMm = $totalSeconds / 60
    $newSs = $totalSeconds % 60
    
    # Format the results as "HH:MM:SS"
    return "{0:D2}:{1:D2}:{2:D2}" -f [Math]::Floor($newHh), [Math]::Floor($newMm), $newSs
}

    # Test case 1: Add 30 seconds
    $result1 = Add-SecondsToTime -Time "12:30:45" -Seconds 30
    $expected1 = "12:31:15"
    if ($result1 -ne $expected1) {
        throw "Test 1 failed: Expected '$expected1', got '$result1'"

    $expected2 = "00:00:00"
    if ($result2 -ne $expected2) {
        throw "Test 2 failed: Expected '$expected2', got '$result2'"
    }

    # Test case 3: Add 1 hour (3600 seconds) to midnight
    $result3 = Add-SecondsToTime -Time "00:00:00" -Seconds 3600
    $expected3 = "01:00:00"
    if ($result3 -ne $expected3) {
        throw "Test 3 failed: Expected '$expected3', got '$result3'"
    }

    # Test case 4: Add exactly one day (86400 seconds)
    $result4 = Add-SecondsToTime -Time "12:00:00" -Seconds 86400
    $expected4 = "12:00:00"
    if ($result4 -ne $expected4) {
        throw "Test 4 failed: Expected '$expected4', got '$result4'"
    }

    $expected5 = "00:30:00"
    if ($result5 -ne $expected5) {

    }

<#
.SYNOPSIS
    Counts the number of similar pairs in a list of words where two words are considered similar if they differ by exactly one character.

.DESCRIPTION
    This script defines a function Count-SimilarPairs that takes an array of words and returns the count of pairs where the words differ by exactly one character.
    The script also includes a test block with hard-coded inputs to demonstrate the function's usage.
#>

function Count-SimilarPairs {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [string[]]$Words
    )

    <#
    .SYNOPSIS
        Checks if two words are similar (differ by exactly one character).

    .DESCRIPTION
        This helper function compares two words character by character and returns true if they differ by exactly one character.
    #>
    function Test-AreSimilar {
        param (
            [string]$Word1,
            [string]$Word2
        )

        $differenceCount = 0
        for ($i = 0; $i -lt $Word1.Length; $i++) {
            if ($Word1[$i] -ne $Word2[$i]) {
                $differenceCount++
            }
            if ($differenceCount -gt 1) {
                return $false
            }
        }
        return $differenceCount -eq 1
    }

    $n = $Words.Count
    $similarPairsCount = 0
    for ($i = 0; $i -lt $n; $i++) {
        for ($j = $i + 1; $j -lt $n; $j++) {
            if (Test-AreSimilar -Word1 $Words[$i] -Word2 $Words[$j]) {
                $similarPairsCount++
            }
        }
    }
    return $similarPairsCount
}

<#
.SYNOPSIS
    Counts the number of valid triplets (A[i], B[j], C[k]) where A[i] < B[j] < C[k].
.DESCRIPTION
    This script takes three sorted arrays A, B, and C, and counts how many triplets exist
    where an element from A is less than an element from B, which in turn is less than an element from C.
    The solution uses binary search for efficient counting.
#>

function Count-ValidTriplets {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory=$true)]
        [int[]]$A,
        
        [Parameter(Mandatory=$true)]
        [int[]]$B,
        
        [Parameter(Mandatory=$true)]
        [int[]]$C
    )
    
    # Sort all input arrays
    $A_sorted = $A | Sort-Object
    $B_sorted = $B | Sort-Object
    $C_sorted = $C | Sort-Object
    
    $total = 0
    
    foreach ($b in $B_sorted) {
        # Count elements in A less than current B element
        $a_count = Find-ElementsLessThan -Array $A_sorted -Value $b
        
        # Count elements in C greater than current B element
        $c_count = Find-ElementsGreaterThan -Array $C_sorted -Value $b
        
        $total += $a_count * $c_count
    }
    
    return $total
}

<#
.SYNOPSIS
    Finds the number of elements in a sorted array less than a given value using binary search.
#>
function Find-ElementsLessThan {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory=$true)]
        [int[]]$Array,
        
        [Parameter(Mandatory=$true)]
        [int]$Value
    )
    
    $left = 0
    $right = $Array.Length - 1
    $result = 0
    
    while ($left -le $right) {
        $mid = [Math]::Floor(($left + $right) / 2)
        
        if ($Array[$mid] -lt $Value) {
            $result = $mid + 1
            $left = $mid + 1
        }
        else {
            $right = $mid - 1
        }
    }
    
    return $result
}

<#
.SYNOPSIS
    Finds the number of elements in a sorted array greater than a given value using binary search.
#>
function Find-ElementsGreaterThan {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory=$true)]
        [int[]]$Array,
        
        [Parameter(Mandatory=$true)]
        [int]$Value
    )
    
    $left = 0
    $right = $Array.Length - 1
    $result = 0
    
    while ($left -le $right) {
        $mid = [Math]::Floor(($left + $right) / 2)
        
        if ($Array[$mid] -gt $Value) {
            $result = $Array.Length - $mid
            $right = $mid - 1
        }
        else {
            $left = $mid + 1
        }
    }
    
    return $result
}

code:
function New-MaxHeap {
    <#
    .SYNOPSIS
        Creates a max heap using negative values from an input array.
    .PARAMETER InputArray
        The array of numbers to be converted into a max heap.
    .RETURNS
        A max heap represented as an array with negative values.
    #>
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int[]]$InputArray
    )
    
    $heap = @()
    foreach ($num in $InputArray) {
        # Use negative values to simulate max heap with min heap
        $heap += -$num
    }
    
    # Heapify the array
    [System.Collections.Generic.List[int]]$list = $heap
    $list.Sort()
    return $list
}

function Process-HeapOperations {
    <#
    .SYNOPSIS
        Processes a series of operations on a max heap and calculates team sums.
    .PARAMETER Heap
        The max heap to process operations on.
    .PARAMETER Operations
        The array of operations to perform.
    .RETURNS
        The difference between team 1 and team 2 sums.
    #>
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [System.Collections.Generic.List[int]]$Heap,
        
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [string[]]$Operations
    )
    
    $sum1 = 0
    $sum2 = 0
    
    foreach ($op in $Operations) {
        $action, $team = $op -split ' '
        
        if ($Heap.Count -eq 0) {
            continue
        }
        
        if ($action -eq 'p') {
            # Pop operation - get the max element (smallest negative)
            $current = -$Heap[0]
            $Heap.RemoveAt(0)
            
            if ($team -eq '1') {
                $sum1 += $current
            }
            else {
                $sum2 += $current
            }
        }
        elseif ($action -eq 'b') {
            # Burn operation - simply remove the max element
            $Heap.RemoveAt(0)
        }
        
        # Re-heapify after each operation
        $Heap.Sort()
    }
    
    return $sum1 - $sum2
}

        [System.Collections.Generic.List[int]]$Heap,
        
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [string[]]$Operations
    )
    
    $sum1 = 0
    $sum2 = 0
    
    foreach ($op in $Operations) {
        $action, $team = $op -split ' '
        
        if ($Heap.Count -eq 0) {
            continue
        }
        
        if ($action -eq 'p') {
            # Pop operation - get the max element (smallest negative)
            $current = -$Heap[0]
            $Heap.RemoveAt(0)
            
            if ($team -eq '1') {
                $sum1 += $current
            }
            else {
                $sum2 += $current
            }
        }
        elseif ($action -eq 'b') {
            # Burn operation - simply remove the max element
            $Heap.RemoveAt(0)
        }
        
        # Re-heapify after each operation
        $Heap.Sort()
    }
    
    return $sum1 - $sum2
}
function Test-HeapOperations {
    # Test Case 1: Basic operations
    $testInput1 = @(10, 20, 30)
    $testOperations1 = @("p 1", "p 2", "b", "p 1")
    $heap1 = New-MaxHeap -InputArray $testInput1
    $result1 = Process-HeapOperations -Heap $heap1 -Operations $testOperations1
    if ($result1 -ne 10) {
        throw "Test Case 1 failed: Expected 10, got $result1"
    }

    # Test Case 2: More operations with empty heap scenario
    $testInput2 = @(5, 3, 8, 1)
    $testOperations2 = @("p 2", "p 1", "b", "p 2", "p 1", "b", "p 1")
    $heap2 = New-MaxHeap -InputArray $testInput2
    $result2 = Process-HeapOperations -Heap $heap2 -Operations $testOperations2
    if ($result2 -ne -4) {
        throw "Test Case 2 failed: Expected -4, got $result2"
    }

    # Test Case 3: All burn operations
    $testInput3 = @(15, 25, 35)
    $testOperations3 = @("b", "b", "b")
    $heap3 = New-MaxHeap -InputArray $testInput3
    $result3 = Process-HeapOperations -Heap $heap3 -Operations $testOperations3
    if ($result3 -ne 0) {
        throw "Test Case 3 failed: Expected 0, got $result3"
    }

    # Test Case 4: Single element heap
    $testInput4 = @(100)
    $testOperations4 = @("p 1", "p 2")
    $heap4 = New-MaxHeap -InputArray $testInput4
    $result4 = Process-HeapOperations -Heap $heap4 -Operations $testOperations4
    if ($result4 -ne 100) {
        throw "Test Case 4 failed: Expected 100, got $result4"
    }

    Write-Output "All test cases passed successfully"
}

<#
.SYNOPSIS
    Removes all instances of a specified number from a list of non-negative integers and returns the modified list along with the count of removed integers.

.DESCRIPTION
    The Remove-NumberFromList function takes a list of non-negative integers and a number to remove. It returns a new list with all instances of the specified number removed, along with the count of how many numbers were removed. The function includes input validation to ensure all parameters meet the required criteria.

.PARAMETER Numbers
    An array of non-negative integers from which the specified number will be removed.

.PARAMETER NumberToRemove
    A non-negative integer that will be removed from the Numbers array.

.EXAMPLE
    Remove-NumberFromList -Numbers @(1, 2, 3, 2, 4) -NumberToRemove 2
    Returns a list @(1, 3, 4) and a count of 2.
#>
function Remove-NumberFromList {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int[]]$Numbers,

        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int]$NumberToRemove
    )

    # Validate that all elements in Numbers are non-negative integers
    if ($Numbers | Where-Object { $_ -lt 0 }) {
        throw "Numbers should contain only non-negative integers"
    }

    # Validate that NumberToRemove is a non-negative integer
    if ($NumberToRemove -lt 0) {
        throw "NumberToRemove must be a non-negative integer"
    }

    $countRemoved = ($Numbers | Where-Object { $_ -eq $NumberToRemove }).Count
    $minimizedList = $Numbers | Where-Object { $_ -ne $NumberToRemove }

    return $minimizedList, $countRemoved
}

code:
<#
.SYNOPSIS
    Performs operations to make all elements of an array zero by subtracting the minimum non-zero element in each step.
.DESCRIPTION
    Given an array of integers, this function performs operations to make all elements zero.
    Each operation involves subtracting the minimum non-zero element from all non-zero elements.
    The function returns the count of non-zero elements subtracted at each step.
.PARAMETER arr
    The array of integers to process.
#>
function Subtract-ToZeroOperations {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int[]]$arr
    )

    $operationsCount = @()

    while ($arr | Where-Object { $_ -ne 0 }) {
        # Find the minimum non-zero element
        $minNonZero = ($arr | Where-Object { $_ -ne 0 } | Measure-Object -Minimum).Minimum
        
        # Perform the subtraction operation
        $arr = $arr | ForEach-Object {
            if ($_ -ne 0) {
                $_ - $minNonZero
            } else {
                $_
            }
        }
        
        # Count non-zero elements before the operation
        $nonZeroCount = ($arr | Where-Object { $_ -ne 0 }).Count + 1
        
        # Add the non-zero count to the list of operations count
        $operationsCount += $nonZeroCount
    }

    return $operationsCount
}

code:
<#
.SYNOPSIS
    Calculates the total visible area of the "Stair Building" and the highest y-coordinate.
.DESCRIPTION
    This function takes the number of levels (n), the area contribution per level (k), and an array of levels (each defined by x and y coordinates).
    It returns the total visible area (n * k) and the highest y-coordinate from the levels.
.PARAMETER n
    The number of levels in the stair building.
.PARAMETER k
    The area contribution per level.
.PARAMETER levels
    An array of tuples (or arrays) where each tuple represents the x and y coordinates of a level.
.OUTPUTS
    Returns a tuple (array in PowerShell) containing the total visible area and the highest y-coordinate.
#>
function Get-StairBuildingVisibleArea {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int]$n,
        
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int]$k,
        
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [array]$levels
    )

    $totalArea = $n * $k
    $highestY = ($levels | ForEach-Object { $_[1] } | Measure-Object -Maximum).Maximum
    
    return $totalArea, $highestY
}

code:
<#
.SYNOPSIS
    Counts the number of good subarrays with exactly k distinct integers.
.DESCRIPTION
    This function uses the sliding window technique to count subarrays with at most k distinct integers,
    then calculates the difference between subarrays with at most k and at most k-1 distinct integers
    to get the count of subarrays with exactly k distinct integers.
#>
function Count-GoodSubarrays {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int]$n,
        
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int]$k,
        
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int[]]$arr
    )

    function AtMostKDistinct {
        param (
            [int[]]$arr,
            [int]$k
        )

        $count = @{}
        $i = 0
        $result = 0

        for ($j = 0; $j -lt $arr.Length; $j++) {
            if (-not $count.ContainsKey($arr[$j])) {
                $count[$arr[$j]] = 0
            }

            if ($count[$arr[$j]] -eq 0) {
                $k--
            }

            $count[$arr[$j]]++

            while ($k -lt 0) {
                $count[$arr[$i]]--
                if ($count[$arr[$i]] -eq 0) {
                    $k++
                }
                $i++
            }

            $result += $j - $i + 1
        }

        return $result
    }

    # Number of subarrays with at most k distinct integers
    $atMostK = AtMostKDistinct -arr $arr -k $k
    # Number of subarrays with at most k-1 distinct integers
    $atMostKMinus1 = AtMostKDistinct -arr $arr -k ($k - 1)
    
    return $atMostK - $atMostKMinus1
}

code:
<#
.SYNOPSIS
    Finds the shortest path from the top-left corner (0, 0) to the bottom-right corner (N-1, M-1) in a grid, avoiding traps marked as '#'.

.DESCRIPTION
    This function uses a breadth-first search (BFS) algorithm to find the shortest path in a grid where some cells are traps ('#').
    The function returns the length of the shortest path or "IMPOSSIBLE" if no such path exists.

.PARAMETER N
    The number of rows in the grid.

.PARAMETER M
    The number of columns in the grid.

.PARAMETER Grid
    A 2D array representing the grid. Each cell can be '.' (empty) or '#' (trap).

.OUTPUTS
    System.Int32 or System.String
    Returns the length of the shortest path as an integer, or "IMPOSSIBLE" if no path exists.
#>
function Get-ShortestPath {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int]$N,
        
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int]$M,
        
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [string[][]]$Grid
    )

    if ($Grid[0][0] -eq '#' -or $Grid[$N-1][$M-1] -eq '#') {
        return "IMPOSSIBLE"
    }

    $directions = @(
        @(1, 0),   # Down
        @(0, 1),   # Right
        @(-1, 0),  # Up
        @(0, -1)   # Left
    )

    $visited = New-Object 'bool[][]' $N
    for ($i = 0; $i -lt $N; $i++) {
        $visited[$i] = New-Object bool[] $M
    }

    $queue = New-Object System.Collections.Generic.Queue[object]
    $queue.Enqueue(@(0, 0, 0))
    $visited[0][0] = $true

    while ($queue.Count -gt 0) {
        $current = $queue.Dequeue()
        $row = $current[0]
        $col = $current[1]
        $dist = $current[2]

        if ($row -eq ($N - 1) -and $col -eq ($M - 1)) {
            return $dist
        }

        foreach ($dir in $directions) {
            $newRow = $row + $dir[0]
            $newCol = $col + $dir[1]

            if ($newRow -ge 0 -and $newRow -lt $N -and $newCol -ge 0 -and $newCol -lt $M) {
                if (-not $visited[$newRow][$newCol] -and $Grid[$newRow][$newCol] -eq '.') {
                    $visited[$newRow][$newCol] = $true
                    $queue.Enqueue(@($newRow, $newCol, $dist + 1))
                }
            }
        }
    }

    return "IMPOSSIBLE"
}

<#
.SYNOPSIS
    Finds the shortest path from the top-left corner (0, 0) to the bottom-right corner (N-1, M-1) in a grid, avoiding traps marked as '#'.

.DESCRIPTION
    This function uses a breadth-first search (BFS) algorithm to find the shortest path in a grid where some cells are traps ('#').
    The function returns the length of the shortest path or "IMPOSSIBLE" if no such path exists.

.PARAMETER N
    The number of rows in the grid.

.PARAMETER M
    The number of columns in the grid.

.PARAMETER Grid
    A 2D array representing the grid. Each cell can be '.' (empty) or '#' (trap).

.OUTPUTS
    System.Int32 or System.String
    Returns the length of the shortest path as an integer, or "IMPOSSIBLE" if no path exists.
#>
function Get-ShortestPath {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int]$N,
        
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int]$M,
        
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [string[][]]$Grid
    )

    if ($Grid[0][0] -eq '#' -or $Grid[$N-1][$M-1] -eq '#') {
        return "IMPOSSIBLE"
    }

    $directions = @(
        @(1, 0),   # Down
        @(0, 1),   # Right
        @(-1, 0),  # Up
        @(0, -1)   # Left
    )

    $visited = New-Object 'bool[][]' $N
    for ($i = 0; $i -lt $N; $i++) {
        $visited[$i] = New-Object bool[] $M
    }

    $queue = New-Object System.Collections.Generic.Queue[object]
    $queue.Enqueue(@(0, 0, 0))
    $visited[0][0] = $true

    while ($queue.Count -gt 0) {
        $current = $queue.Dequeue()
        $row = $current[0]
        $col = $current[1]
        $dist = $current[2]

        if ($row -eq ($N - 1) -and $col -eq ($M - 1)) {
            return $dist
        }

        foreach ($dir in $directions) {
            $newRow = $row + $dir[0]
            $newCol = $col + $dir[1]

            if ($newRow -ge 0 -and $newRow -lt $N -and $newCol -ge 0 -and $newCol -lt $M) {
                if (-not $visited[$newRow][$newCol] -and $Grid[$newRow][$newCol] -eq '.') {
                    $visited[$newRow][$newCol] = $true
                    $queue.Enqueue(@($newRow, $newCol, $dist + 1))
                }
            }
        }
    }

    return "IMPOSSIBLE"
}
function Test-GetShortestPath {
    # Test Case 1: Simple 3x3 grid with one obstacle
    $grid1 = @(
        @('.', '.', '.'),
        @('.', '#', '.'),
        @('.', '.', '.')
    )
    $result1 = Get-ShortestPath -N 3 -M 3 -Grid $grid1
    if ($result1 -ne 4) {
        throw "Test Case 1 failed: Expected 4, got $result1"
    }

    # Test Case 2: 2x2 grid with blocked path
    $grid2 = @(
        @('.', '#'),
        @('#', '.')
    )
    $result2 = Get-ShortestPath -N 2 -M 2 -Grid $grid2
    if ($result2 -ne "IMPOSSIBLE") {
        throw "Test Case 2 failed: Expected 'IMPOSSIBLE', got $result2"
    }

    # Test Case 3: 4x4 grid with a central block
    $grid3 = @(
        @('.', '.', '.', '.'),
        @('.', '#', '#', '.'),
        @('.', '#', '#', '.'),
        @('.', '.', '.', '.')
    )
    $result3 = Get-ShortestPath -N 4 -M 4 -Grid $grid3
    if ($result3 -ne 6) {
        throw "Test Case 3 failed: Expected 6, got $result3"
    }

    # Test Case 4: Single cell grid
    $grid4 = @(
        @('.')
    )
    $result4 = Get-ShortestPath -N 1 -M 1 -Grid $grid4
    if ($result4 -ne 0) {
        throw "Test Case 4 failed: Expected 0, got $result4"
    }

    Write-Output "All test cases passed"
}

Test-GetShortestPath

<#
.SYNOPSIS
    Determines which answer is more likely to be human-generated by comparing word matches with a question.
.DESCRIPTION
    This script compares two answers to a question by counting how many words from each answer appear in the question.
    It then uses cross-multiplication to determine which answer has a higher match ratio without using floating-point division.
#>

function Compare-Answers {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [string[]]$Question,
        
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [string[]]$Answer1,
        
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [string[]]$Answer2
    )

    # Create a hashtable of question words for faster lookup
    $questionWords = @{}
    foreach ($word in $Question) {
        $questionWords[$word] = $true
    }

    # Count matching words in each answer
    $count1 = 0
    foreach ($word in $Answer1) {
        if ($questionWords.ContainsKey($word)) {
            $count1++
        }
    }

    $count2 = 0
    foreach ($word in $Answer2) {
        if ($questionWords.ContainsKey($word)) {
            $count2++
        }
    }

    # Get lengths of the answers
    $len1 = $Answer1.Count
    $len2 = $Answer2.Count

    # Compare using cross-multiplication
    if ($count1 * $len2 -lt $count2 * $len1) {
        return "NUMBER TWO IS THE HUMAN"
    }
    else {
        return "NUMBER ONE IS THE HUMAN"
    }
}

    # Test case 1

<#
.SYNOPSIS
    Determines if an array can be sorted within k adjacent swaps.
.DESCRIPTION
    This function calculates the minimum number of adjacent swaps needed to sort an array using a bubble sort approach.
    It then compares this number with the given k value to determine if sorting within k swaps is possible.
.PARAMETER Heights
    The array of heights to be sorted.
.PARAMETER K
    The maximum number of adjacent swaps allowed.
.OUTPUTS
    Returns the number of swaps needed if it's less than or equal to k, otherwise returns -1.
#>
function Test-SortWithinSwaps {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int[]]$Heights,
        
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int]$K
    )

    $n = $Heights.Count
    $swapsNeeded = 0
    $auxList = $Heights.Clone()

    for ($i = 0; $i -lt $n; $i++) {
        for ($j = 0; $j -lt ($n - 1 - $i); $j++) {
            if ($auxList[$j] -gt $auxList[$j + 1]) {
                # Swap elements
                $temp = $auxList[$j]
                $auxList[$j] = $auxList[$j + 1]
                $auxList[$j + 1] = $temp
                $swapsNeeded++
            }
        }
    }

    # Return swaps needed if within k, otherwise -1
    if ($swapsNeeded -le $K) {
        return $swapsNeeded
    } else {
        return -1
    }
}

<#
.SYNOPSIS
    Validates if a transaction ID follows the specified format: starts with a letter followed by 5 alphanumeric characters.
.DESCRIPTION
    This function checks if the provided transaction ID matches the pattern ^[A-Za-z][A-Za-z0-9]{5}$.
.PARAMETER transactionId
    The transaction ID to validate.
#>
function Test-TransactionId {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [string]$transactionId
    )

    $pattern = '^[A-Za-z][A-Za-z0-9]{5}$'
    return $transactionId -match $pattern
}

<#
.SYNOPSIS
    Calculates the total amount for a list of transactions.
.DESCRIPTION
    This function sums up the 'amount' field from all transactions in the provided list.
.PARAMETER transactions
    An array of hashtables where each hashtable contains 'id' (string) and 'amount' (double) keys.
#>
function Get-TotalTransactionAmount {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [System.Collections.Hashtable[]]$transactions
    )

    $total = 0.0
    foreach ($transaction in $transactions) {
        $total += $transaction['amount']
    }
    return $total
}

<#
.SYNOPSIS
    Classifies a transaction based on its amount.
.DESCRIPTION
    This function categorizes a transaction as 'small', 'medium', or 'large' based on its amount.
.PARAMETER transaction
    A hashtable containing 'id' (string) and 'amount' (double) keys.
#>
function Get-TransactionType {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [System.Collections.Hashtable]$transaction
    )

    $amount = $transaction['amount']
    if ($amount -lt 100) {
        return 'small'
    } elseif ($amount -lt 1000) {
        return 'medium'
    } else {
        return 'large'
    }
}

# Find-MostPopularPost calculates the most popular post based on a scoring system.
# The score is calculated as: likes + 3 * comments + 5 * shares.
# The function takes the number of posts (n) and an array of posts as input.
# Each post is an array containing post_id, num_likes, num_comments, and num_shares.
function Find-MostPopularPost {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [int]$n,
        
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [array]$posts
    )

    # Internal function to calculate the score for a post
    function Calculate-Score {
        param (
            [int]$likes,
            [int]$comments,
            [int]$shares
        )
        return $likes + 3 * $comments + 5 * $shares
    }

    $maxScore = -1
    $mostPopularPost = ""

    foreach ($post in $posts) {
        $postId = $post[0]
        $numLikes = [int]$post[1]
        $numComments = [int]$post[2]
        $numShares = [int]$post[3]
        
        $score = Calculate-Score -likes $numLikes -comments $numComments -shares $numShares
        
        if ($score -gt $maxScore) {
            $maxScore = $score
            $mostPopularPost = $postId
        }
    }

    return $mostPopularPost
}

# Calculate-Orthocenter computes the orthocenter of a triangle given the coordinates of its three vertices.
# The orthocenter is the intersection point of the three altitudes of a triangle.
# This function takes three points (A, B, C) as input and returns the coordinates of the orthocenter.
function Calculate-Orthocenter {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [double]$Ax,
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [double]$Ay,
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [double]$Bx,
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [double]$By,
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [double]$Cx,
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [double]$Cy
    )

    # Compute coefficients for the two altitude equations
    $a1 = $Cx - $Bx
    $b1 = $Cy - $By
    $c1 = $a1 * $Ax + $b1 * $Ay

    $a2 = $Cx - $Ax
    $b2 = $Cy - $Ay
    $c2 = $a2 * $Bx + $b2 * $By

    # Calculate determinant
    $D = $a1 * $b2 - $a2 * $b1

    # Compute coordinates of the orthocenter
    $x = ($c1 * $b2 - $c2 * $b1) / $D
    $y = ($a1 * $c2 - $a2 * $c1) / $D

    return $x, $y
}

# Calculate-Orthocenter computes the orthocenter of a triangle given the coordinates of its three vertices.
# The orthocenter is the intersection point of the three altitudes of a triangle.
# This function takes three points (A, B, C) as input and returns the coordinates of the orthocenter.
function Calculate-Orthocenter {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param (
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [double]$Ax,
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [double]$Ay,
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [double]$Bx,
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [double]$By,
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [double]$Cx,
        [Parameter(Mandatory = $true)]
        [double]$Cy
    )

    # Compute coefficients for the two altitude equations
    $a1 = $Cx - $Bx
    $b1 = $Cy - $By
    $c1 = $a1 * $Ax + $b1 * $Ay

    $a2 = $Cx - $Ax
    $b2 = $Cy - $Ay
    $c2 = $a2 * $Bx + $b2 * $By

    # Calculate determinant
    $D = $a1 * $b2 - $a2 * $b1

    # Compute coordinates of the orthocenter
    $x = ($c1 * $b2 - $c2 * $b1) / $D
    $y = ($a1 * $c2 - $a2 * $c1) / $D

    return $x, $y
}
function Test-Orthocenter {
    # Test case 1: Right-angled triangle
    $x1, $y1 = Calculate-Orthocenter -Ax 0 -Ay 0 -Bx 3 -By 0 -Cx 0 -Cy 4
    if ([math]::Round($x1, 6) -ne 0 -or [math]::Round($y1, 6) -ne 0) {
        throw "Test 1 failed: Expected (0, 0), got ($([math]::Round($x1, 6)), $([math]::Round($y1, 6)))"
    }

    # Test case 2: Scalene triangle
    $x2, $y2 = Calculate-Orthocenter -Ax 1 -Ay 1 -Bx 2 -By 4 -Cx 5 -Cy 3
    if ([math]::Round($x2, 6) -ne 2 -or [math]::Round($y2, 6) -ne 4) {
        throw "Test 2 failed: Expected (2, 4), got ($([math]::Round($x2, 6)), $([math]::Round($y2, 6)))"
    }

    # Test case 3: Triangle with negative coordinates
    $x3, $y3 = Calculate-Orthocenter -Ax -2 -Ay 1 -Bx 3 -By -4 -Cx 0 -Cy 5
    if ([math]::Round($x3, 6) -ne -5 -or [math]::Round($y3, 6) -ne 0) {
        throw "Test 3 failed: Expected (-5, 0), got ($([math]::Round($x3, 6)), $([math]::Round($y3, 6)))"
    }

    Write-Output "All tests passed successfully"
}
